value.title: Smart Cities: How Facial Recognition Can Facilitate The Safe Return To Urban Life
value.excerpt: When deployed correctly and used to its highest potential, facial recognition technology can help facilitate safe interactions and support a flourishing economy.

value.title: Civil Rights Groups Take Aim at Facial Recognition Tech in Stores
value.excerpt: Three dozen civil rights organizations have called on retailers to stop using the tech, saying “prioritizing profit over privacy is wrong.”

value.title: Report: Computer vision adoption expected to grow significantly in the near future

value.title: Michigan man wrongfully accused with facial recognition urges Congress to act
value.excerpt: A House Judiciary panel heard testimony from Robert Williams, who was mistakenly arrested by the Detroit Police Department based on flawed use of facial recognition software.

value.title: Port of Seattle permanently bans use of facial recognition at Sea-Tac Airport
value.excerpt: The Port of Seattle is enacting a first-of-its-kind permanent ban on the use of facial recognition for law enforcement, security, and surveillance purposes.

value.title: Festo advances robot programming with AI

value.title: The Assault on Our Privacy Is Being Conducted in Private
value.excerpt: Central databases are exploited by criminals, governments and companies that want to part consumers from their money.

value.title: How Octopuses Upend What We Know About Ourselves
value.excerpt: Octopuses (it’s incorrect to say “octopi,” to my despair) are having a moment: There are award-winning books, documentaries and even science fiction about them. I suspect it’s the same hunger that leaves many of us yearning to know aliens: How do radically different minds work?

value.title: Chinese City Using Facial Recognition Tech To Fight Coronavirus
value.excerpt: Facial recognition tech linked to personal health codes has been rolled out in a Chinese city bordering Myanmar as authorities seek to squash a coronavirus outbreak.

value.title: GM Ventures Increases Funding In AI Vision Software Company Algolux
value.excerpt: Algolux, an AI software company based out of Quebec, has announced the closure of series B funding, raising $18.4 million to help accelerate market adoption of the company’s scalable computer vision and image optimization solutions.

value.title: Exynos flagship chipsets: A history of Samsung's homegrown silicon

value.title: US sanctions a Chinese facial recognition company with Silicon Valley funding

value.title: Optimize workforce in your store using Amazon Rekognition

value.title: Maine Becomes First State To Pass Broad Government Ban on Facial Recognition Technology
value.excerpt: Maine's new law is both the strongest and broadest in scope as of yet. The new bill bans the use of facial recognition technology across all levels of state government.

value.title: Analysis-'Racist' facial recognition sparks ethical concerns in Russia
value.excerpt: From scanning residents’ faces to let them into their building to spotting police suspects in a crowd, the rise of facial recognition is accompanied by a growing chorus of concern about unethical uses of the technology.
